print_settings.Notes:: At the included scale and 0.2mm layer height, you can probably get away with as little as 5° (nearly horizontal) support threshold.  This will result in just 4 tiny islands of support that are extremely easy to remove after printing.  If you have problems, just bump up the threshold a little and that should solve any problems.

title: Low poly Falcon Heavy - hollow exhaust

description.text:
This is a remix of a remix. All credit for this original model and idea go to [Doctorwatson's original thing], and thanks to him for making this wonderful piece!

Then, [ThatDutchGuy's remix] make it much easier to print by slicing it into 3 convenient pieces for multicolor printing and print volume limitations.

However, one problem is that the exhaust is solid. If you print it with 0% infill...well, its not possible to print with 0% infill correctly. It will air print significantly at several points during the print. This is a problem if you want to do something cool, like put an LED inside the exhaust to make it glow, or want it semi-transparent but without ugly infill structures visible.

So, I've made this remix as the solution! The exhaust has been hollowed out so it can be printed hollow using conventional removable supports. In fact, at 0.15mm layer height, I was able to print this using minimal supports with a 5° support threshold (almost horizontal) and will scale down a bit and scale up as much as you want. It's not too thin and not too thick - just right. STL is manifold and error-free.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15mm

Infill:

Doesn't matter

Notes:

At the included scale and 0.2mm layer height, you can probably get away with as little as 5° (nearly horizontal) support threshold. This will result in just 4 tiny islands of support that are extremely easy to remove after printing. If you have problems, just bump up the threshold a little and that should solve any problems.

comments.text: Luckily Cura 3 has a setting for wrapping up all the tiny supports into one large structure "Support Join Distance" so I was able to get all supports into one structure and make it fairly robust.  A setting of 10mm worked great.

description.text:
Converting Inkscape .svg files (paths only) into .scad files, useable for further processing using OpenSCAD.org
Version: 0.005

This is an early release of svg2scad command-line tool (perl script) and works with
  • Linux,
  • Windows (with Cygwin.com installed) and
  • MacOS-X.
    • Note: This is NOT a graphical user-interface program, but a command-line tool - but it's still very useful. If you want to export from Inkscape direct, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25036 Unpack package after download:
    % tar xzf svg2scad-0.005.tar.gz and read README (a few perl modules to be installed, quite easy) Limitations:
  • only Inkscape .svg files supported (for now)
  • convert all forms in Inkscape to paths (even circles)
  • SVG text converted to paths do not work well as .scad-files / OpenSCAD has some polygon restrictions (e.g. "T" renders, where as "O" does not, see sample image)
    • Features:
    You can edit 2D path(s) with Inkscape in all tiny details and export it as polygon(s) as .scad and process it (linear_extrude, rotate_extrude etc) with OpenSCAD to do incredible forms. I will release new versions at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28108 direct, and on https://github.com/Spiritdude/SVG2SCAD History:
    -2012/08/12: 0.005: -openrot switch, to make first/last coord x-pos the same (rotate_extrude() requires that), see updated README
    -2012/08/03: 0.003: discovering inconsistancy in path definition, hacking myself to support it
    -2012/08/02: 0.002: extended with some functionality
    -2012/08/01: 0.001: first rudimentary version Q: I'm rather new to OpenSCAD, so I ask for some feedback from experienced OpenSCAD users how to convert multiple paths to a single .scad file, any suggestions? Right now multiple paths are "union() { }" enclosed as polygons, so they can't be individually referenced anymore.

description.text:
Since I have received my printer, I have always thought the 4 wheels/4 level points bed was a pretty bad design from a mechanical point of view.
After checking a few designs, I have taken inspiration from various 3 wheels carriages and have decided to design my own 3 wheels/3 level points bed support.

This bed support is a bit longer than the original, but you can still use the full bed size (small bed) if you set your printer structure correctly (move the arch backwards by ~15mm)

To use this bed support, you'll need to tweak your printing bed to put an intermediate support point between 2 of the original 4 points.
On mine, I did that by adding a 3 holes steel spacer (more details to come)

The setting block doesn't require supports.
Supports are needed only for the Bed_center part, where the different arms will anchor.

To make the final assembly, you will need :

  • 3x original wheels
  • 3x original M5*30 bolts for the wheels
  • 1x original nylon spacer for the wheel on the setting block
  • 3x M5*15 bolts for arms main attachement
  • 6x M4*12 bolts for lateral arms anchor
  • 2x M4*35 bolts for setting block

title: Laser cutting material template remixed for Glowforge

description.text:
This is a remix of the Laser cutting materiale template by Noloxs. The Glowforge recognizes each vector as its own entity and therefore one would have to set each shade of grey on the color wheel separately. To fix this, the color wheel needed to be embedded as a raster image into the svg file in order to use dithering or vary by power. I also removed Noloxs logo so you could add your own there if you like.

The file was edited in Inkscape so it should work in any vector program. There are a few things to remember below.

To use:
Glowforge does not recognize text at this time. There are 2 ways around this.

One is to select all, deselect the color wheel, and then converts all objects to path. This turns the text into paths. Now save as a new svg as the text is no longer editable, so you will want to maintain an original for future tests.

Second option is to save the file as a pdf. Again, make sure it is not removing your orginal svg file because you need it for editing.

Once imported into GFUI and material is selected, click on the color wheel and change it to manual if you are using proofgrade material. Then select vary power if you want to see depth changes by power.

description.text:
This is a Filament Cleaning Clamp that you clamp over the 1.75mm filament with a microfiber cloth interface material that you have to cut and provide. It cleans the filament from dust and small residues that collect on the filament from the environment before it enters the extrude. I highly recommended using a filament filter specially in dusty dirty environments.

Microfiber cloth is used because it provides lower friction and picks up dust effectively.
You do not need to use oil with this filter.

                               --------Instructions--------
  • Simply cut a 4x2cm piece of microfiber cloth (preferably a fine cloth not too thick)
  • Place the cloth over the filament and push the clamp over the filament and cloth so that the clamp holds the cloth on the filament.
  • At this point the cloth should clean the filament while still being able to slide on the filament.

Hopefully this helps to reduce clogs and increase print consistency and quality.
:)

print_settings.Notes:: BloqChain

description.text:
When I made the BloqChain it hit me - I had to have nunchucks to use those with. Born was the NumbChuck. Print two of those and six of the BloqChain things for it all to make sense.

The lighter you go on the infill the less they hurt. For example 5% infill and 3 perimeters, top and bottom layers made mine plenty strong but kept them light enough to be not too painful.

Of course these nunchucks are a joke. They are a fun toy to swing around and be forgotten shortly after.

Please still be careful and do not use on anyone who didn't ask for it.

Printed at 75% infill for both BloqChain links as well as NumbChuck these nunchucks will seriously hurt - so do not do that, please!

No pain, no gain ...

Actually please make sure not to assemble all the chain links before connecting those to each other and of course to the NumbChuck(s). Other than that there is little assembly required.

To make calibration easy, use this large easy to print piece. 110mm for x and y, 4mm height. All squares are 10mm x 10mm.
The difference to smaller calibration pieces is that you can find really tiny errors with this. I found a 2% error in my print, 3 mm at this size. A standard 20mm calibration cube would have given you a .4mm difference. Still measurable but a lot more difficult.

Print, cool, measure, calibrate, print again, measure, calibrate again :)
Calibration is done like this
Get your X or Y calibration value from Slicer.
Measure the X or Y length of the piece
Use following formula
(110 x OldCalib) / Measurement = NewCalib
So my old value was 61.2555 for X and I measured 107.50mm. 
110 x 61.2555 = 6738.105
6738.105 / 107.5 = 62.6800
So i now have a better calibrated bot!

comments.text:
I have a little problem with the squares 10mm x 10mm
my Print is 9.65 x 9.65 mm can i fix it ?
comments.author: el_diabolo

comments.text:
I'm sure you've solved it by now, but for others who might be curious:
10/9.65=1.036 (this basically tells you that your size is about 3.6% under what we want)
Then apply that number to whatever your current 'steps per mm' setting are in your firmware (or EEPROM settings if you don't want to recompile and reflash). So lets say your current X and Y steps per mm are 78.1, you would do this:
1.035*78.1=80.83 <---(just plug that new value in for x and y steps per mm)
Don't forget to save your firmware settings!
comments.author: el_diabolo

comments.text:
expected / measured = multiplier
...then...
multiplier * old_steps_per_mm = new_steps_per_mm
...just seems a lot simpler to me. :)

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I've made these to be used with an Anet E12 springs on the bed levelling.

The 2.5mm hole spring caps are for the top and can either be tapped out M3, or just screw an M3 countersunk screw through them. The 4.0mm holes are clearance and go on the bottom of the spring.

I've used these with M3 x 40mm countersunk screws so there is plenty of screw for the adjusted to connect to.

Once done up, the spring seems to hold to the top and bottom caps and they don't fall off easily. Handy if you take the heated bed off the printer.

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

Centrifugal fan for 24.5x18.5mm (plane measurements) 5V DC motor.

Assembly tips:

  • Fan center hole is a bit smaller than the motor shaft, either adjust with a small drill or heat fit if using PLA.
  • The fan seems to self align a bit with high RPM, so some wobble/scratching when moving manually might not be a problem.
  • Add insert while running to just before it starts scratching for a tight fit and add glue to the seam.

Remix of Warren_3Deee Squirrel-cage fan, changes are: ,

  • enlargened about 50% to fit a 24.5x18.5 motor
  • Changed fan to a more agressive blade pitch and merged parts for single print.
  • Modified endcap/insert to limit leakage.
  • Misc cuts/tweaks.

description.text:
Remix of Anubis123's remix of Firesped's blower fan duct. I made the following changes:

description.text:
This is a replacement Herman Miller Aeron armrest guide/indexer for the earlier model chairs that use a spring. Later on the design was updated to not use a spring. The picture of the black piece is my original broken guide.

I designed this piece because I could not find a replacement anywhere. This model is really close and works with sanding but may need to be modified to work directly off the printer. I think the hole is slightly too small and the guide channel is slightly too small. This may however have been a problem with my printer. I've been having some filament issues and my print was pretty rough around the edges as a result.

If you print this let me know if the model worked first try or if you had to sand it down some. I also uploaded the solidworks model if you would like to tweak it yourself.

Printer:

Qidi Tech 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

Notes:

This was printed in PLA. I'm sure ABS would work just as well.

Installation Instructions

I had to sand down the inside of the the pivot hole and the guide channel to get this part to articulate smoothly on the armrest frame. A dremel worked great for this.

To install this piece on the armrest place it on the armrest frame with the spring cutout facing towards the seat. See Picture 1.

Place the armrest with the cover removed on the frame over the guide. Install the two bolts. Then slide the straight arm of the spring down into the cutout. This will have the other end of the spring resting on the top edge of the armrest. You will then have to use some pliers to compress the spring and tuck it under the lip of the armrest. I don't have pictures of this process but an extra set of hands might help get the spring in place. It took me by myself quite a while. Picture 2 is what the armrest should look like after this process.

Just put the armrest covers back on and you should be good to go.

Picture 1. Guide on Armrest frame. Please note that this is the left armrest. Picture 2. Armrest reassembled with spring in place. Please note that this is the right armrest.

comments.text: I should have checked here first. I just modeled my owned and printed it out last night and installed it minutes ago only to find that you've already made one. I came here to see if I should refine the model and put it up on Thingiverse. So even though I didn't use yours thanks for the effort.

description.text:
This is a 3d printable version of the famous Klingberg Wing.
Important!
Download the latest version of the files before printing.
About:

The Klingberg Wing is probably one of the best flying wings for R/C there is, It was designed by the brilliant Rol Klingberg and was kitted by FutureFlight many years ago.

Have a look at the plans:
https://aerofred.com/details.php?image_id=99527

This is a smaller version of the 2 mater span KW, sized to 1.3 meter, fully printable on 200mm by 200mm by 180mm volume 3d printers.

Specs:

Span: 1320mm
Print weight:320g
Area 19,2 dm2

Recommended Gear:

3s1800 or 3s 2200 or 4s 1300
28mm outrunner or 32mm outrunner
5 grams servos
Corona digital MG 5 dollar servos from HK

At 620 grams the wing loading is 32,2 g/dm2.

All Up Weight as a glider 400 grams?? I haven´t tested that yet.
All Up Weight with motor and 3s 2200 Battery less than 600 grams

I´m including in this listing all the STL files, 5 sections per wing panel plus hatch, servo covers and hatch covers.

The KW was a glider and could have a pusher motor, they used a .10 cox I think, we will use an electric 28mm or 32mm diameter.

Notes:

At this time I´m releasing a slope glider version that has a gear pocket where a 3s 2200mA/h battery can be fit, soon I´ll be releasing a pusher motor pod that will be glued on top of the wing as can be seen in the print screens. You can start printing before the pod is out because it will be made to glue on the wing skin as seen in the pictures.

I have not flown this wing but it was made over the original plan, the airfoils are the same, the washout, the angles, all the same as the original, only 1,3meter instead of 2 meter span.

I´m also including in this listing factory files so you can print tune the settings to your printer and Gcode files for a 200X200X180 mm direct drive machine, will work on an original Prusa or any similar machine.

The C.G. is from 54% to 62% of the chord length from the leading edge
To do:

Skid
Maybe a tricycle landing gear

Ordering Prints:

I´ll be offering prints of this wing for anyone interested, will add that listing to the site in the next few days as possible.

https://aerofred.com

File Naming:

W-wing
WL-Wing Left
SPC-Servio Pocket Cover
HC-Hatch Cover
HCLR-Hatch Cover Left Right
A-Aileron
MP-Motor Pod

Change Log

3/3/2018
1.Corrected one of the wing gcodes, the bed temp was 56 instead of 60C.
2.Added all separate gcodes.
3.Included files for a prototype with 1 meter span I did before this final version.
4.Addedthe servo pocket covers in stl, gcode and .factory formats
4/3/2018
1.Added the motor pod
8-3/2018
1.Added splitted stl´s for 150mm on Z machines.
10/3/2018
1.Added the skids

I hope you like this printable flying wing, one of my favourite FW of all time.
Please submit your makes to Thingiverse and post your questions and ideas on the comments, this will help me to improve the design.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,25 Layer Height 0,40 Nozzle

Infill:

no

Notes:

There is no infill, the design already has the necessary structure to hold the single wall skin. Section 1 L and R need supports just to form the hatch inlay.

Please use Simplify3D to open the factory files and see the print settings for yourself.

You can print this wing in 3 sessions using the files named 200X200 or print the parts in separate using the files from the Gcodes Separated folder.

description.text:
I modified the holes to be M3 only, because that's what I have and what I like to use.
The NodeMCU might require to enlarge the holes a little bit with a drill, but I tried and you can also use M3 as is.
In my case, I didn't want to have a loose-jumper cables-setup so I chose to put some headers on a piece of perfboard and use the cable that came with the SDS011 so it's plug-and-play, more error-resistant (no cables falling out or something) while still not requiring soldering the ESP board into the project so it can be reused.
I then put a large enough hole into the perfboard and that's my setup.
I'm not too sure if the rest of the project uses any M2 screws, if it does I will modify those files and upload them here as well!

title: LED Matrix Modular Case System
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have designed the following modular parts for constructing cases for the popular cascadable dot matrix LED display modules

The MAX7219 Dot Matrix Display Modules I used measured:-
130mm x 32mm x12mm (all approx.)

The design can accomodate any number of these modules by stacking the case parts in various ways.

e.g.

For a single module you can use either:-
         A middle section + 1 male end cap + 1 female end cap.
         OR
         1 Male end + 1 Female end.

For two modules you can use:-
        A Middle section + 1 Male end + 1 Female end.
        OR
        2 x Middle section + 1 Male end cap + 1 Female end cap.

For Three modules you can use:-
        2 x Middle sections + 1 Male end + 1 Female end.

        etc.

The parts 'click' together by using a tongue and groove system (male = tongue, female = groove).

As designed, the parts print on a Vertex 8400 printer with a 0.35 nozzle and fit together nicely.

The case parts have a slot for the LED modules to slide into and side 'cheeks' that keep the LED devices aligned.

The case also has a front slot to accomodate a piece of 3.0mm thick red transparent acrylic sheet.

The acrylic sheet should be cut to 45.0mm in height in order to be a good sliding fit in the slots.

Cut the sheet to the length to suit the number of modules in use.

The case has ample room in the rear cavity to accomodate an Arduino Micro or an ESP8266 NodeMCU controller board.

I used sticky pads to stick the electronics to the back of the LED modules and then slid the complete assembly in to the case.

I made a small slot in the rear of the case for a USB power lead after printing the parts.

The SketchUp files are provided so that the design can be adapted to other LED modules, controllers etc. I used SketchUp Make version 17.3.116.

Printing hints:

If you use a 'brim' on the bottom layer to help the parts stick to the bed
you will have to clean out the groove in the middle section with a knife or similar tool after printing.

The Middle section and End parts take a long time to print (6+ hours on my printer), to check that the tongue and groove system will work with your printer I suggest that you print the Male and Female end caps first as test pieces.

Continuous fitting and releasing the parts will wear the tongue and groove system and the fit will become loose.

Printer:

VERTEX 8400

General fan duct for 3D printers with 20x10x15 mm hotend block

  • The adaptor fits in a 50 mm radial fan and can be fixed on the fan with a M4x30 mm
  • The nozzle inlet has a 1mm flange which slides in the adaptor base, right in front of the fan outlet.
  • The third part is the holder for a 50 mm radial fan which gives you the opportunity to fix the assembly on your printer.

PS:
On my K8200, I have moved the original fan holder to the back side of the Z-carriage aluminium support and have fixed the assembly with a M4x25 mm on it
That is not a perfect print - a draft prototype which was printed with almost no cooling air - but I have uploaded the photo anyway.

• Having enough space between the hotend block and the fan nozzle body - in case, if you want to have insulation or cover on the hotend block)
  • Aiming the air flow toward a point below the head of the nozzle - you can see the nozzle outlet has about 3mm narrow channel with a downward inclinaiton. It guides the air to cool down the already printed layers instead of the hotend.
  • Mount for the nozzle was designed as a separated part and with an sliding mechanism. In case you need to modify the nozzle or replace a damaged one with another, one can easily slide the former nozzle and replace it...
  • Leave a comments, if you have an idea to improve and optimize this design

Habe hier eine Halterung entworfen um den Extruder Motor aktiv zu kühlen. Hatte extreme Probleme mit der Überlastung/Überhitzung des Extruder Motors. (ja, ich habe wochenlang alles an EInstellungen versucht um dieses Problem in den Griff zu bekommen...!)
Der Motor wurde immer bis zu 50°C warm was dann dazu führte das er irgendwann nicht mehr genug Kraft hatte das Filament zu fördern und dann gerade bei vielen retracts übersprang (Extruder skipping nennt man das wohl) Dachte am Anfang das Filament würde durchrutschen oder zerquetscht werden, das war es aber nicht....Resultat in dieser Zeit: ein Fehldruck nach dem anderen. Und bei Facebook und Co berichten viele von diesem Problem.

Habe den Noctua 40x10 12V Lüfter verbaut. (nicht zu hören) jeder andere 40 mm Lüfter passt aber auch. Es ist Platz genug um zwischen Motor und Lüfter noch einen passiven Kühlkörper 40x40x10 zu montieren. (ist aber eigentlich gar nicht mehr nötig.

Die Fotos zeigen noch die erste Version bei der die Seitenteile etwas zu dünn waren.
Kühlung sollte auch auf alle anderen Motoren passen sofern genug Platz drunter ist.
Gedruckt habe ich mit Cura 3.2 mit Verwendung der Baumstütz Struktur.

Hab noch ein Bild mit einem aufgeklebten Kühlkörper zugefügt.

You can secure the mount to foam or wood structures using your glue of choice. I would not recommend hot glue for obvious reasons. :p I do recommend scuffing up the base with a low-grit sandpaper for better surface adhesion.

title: Printrbot Simple Bowden Attachment 1.75mm filament - 4mm or 10mm Fitting

description.text:
Fits the Printrbot Simple 2014 with the aluminum extruder. Printing is soooooo much smoother, quieter and more accurate with a Bowden setup. I'm using an AirTripper with 10mm fittings - super awesome! You'll need several M3 size bolts in a few lengths:
  • 2 - M3 20mm bolts (preferably with threads running the entire length. For securing hot end.
  • 2 - M3 15mm bolts - For securing attachment to motor plate.
  • 1 - M3 6mm bolt - maybe longer depending on if you're using the stock front Y mount or not... this is to secure the front of the attachment to motor plate where there is little clearance because of horizontal bolts securing hot end.
    • Included is the OpenSCAD file so you can fiddle with the mounts if need be. Your hot-end diameter might be a beaver hair too large, and a few rounds of plumbers tape should give it a nice fit. Photos Coming Soon By the way - the stupid customizer is not working as expected and I can't remove the Tag. So sorry. However - if you are up to editing the OpenSCAD file you'll be fine.

comments.text: I ran into a problem with the wall width. If I make it more than 2.9mm,  it fills in the whole box just making it a filled cube.
comments.author: ipp

comments.text:
Try increasing the corner_radius which is 3 mm by default. If the value for the wall_thickness is larger than corner_radius the cutout section in the lip module won't work.
Look at the line in the lip module
cylinder(h = lip_height+.2, r = corner_radius-wall_thickness);
you're ending up with a negative radius value here.
For a 3 mm wall_thickness try 5 mm corner radius which should give you a nicely rounded interior. If those two values are too close you'd get more of a sharp corner than roundness. Since you're cutting this on a CNC machine, I'd make the corner_radius by at least half the diameter of the bit you're using larger than the wall thickness.
comments.author: HungryHam

comments.text: Thanks. I missed that when looking at the code. I'll let you know how it works out.

title: Ryobi Battery Pack to AC Adapter

description.text:
I inherited a bunch of Ryobi products with no batteries, and I'm not a big fan of battery powered tools anyways, as I've never felt like I got my money's worth out of them before they go, so I took Ryobi Li-Ion Battery Pack by SoundDoc and cut out parts that I didn't need, shortened the platform and added some holes for my power receptacles.
Great work by SoundDoc on the battery model. I didn’t have an actual battery to copy and there’s no way I was doing it from scratch. Thank you so much!
Its working well for my needs with my bench power supply at only 12v but I'll be on the look out for an 18v supply in the future.

Printed in PLA on the fastest settings. Everything needed supports due to the complex shapes, but printed quickly, cleaned up easily and the parts snapped together tightly.
Springs and contact pads came from an old car power plug from a radar detector.

Electricity can be nasty so do this stuff at your own risk.
BE SAFE EVERYONE!

This is a mirror holder for optical experiments. This component is part of the Open-source optics project, whose goal is to radically reduce the cost of scientific optical hardware: by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group. For similar see the Open-Source Lab How to Build Your Own Hardware and Reduce Research Costs

Use the OpenSCAD files to customize it for your application, print on your favorite open source 3-D printer and enjoy. The mirror mount consists of three components: the metal rod, the plastic base, and the mirror holder. The mirror holder is not open source and is a commercial kinematic mirror mount from Thor Labs, the KM100 (We will work on an open source version later). This open-source mirror holder is designed to hold the mirror on a smooth 8mm diameter rod. If you need the base go to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28133 Full information here: http://www.appropedia.org/Open-source_mirror_mount For a completely open-source mirror mount see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30727 Thanks to Xin and Nick for designs. This component is part of the Open-source Optics Library: Zhang C, Anzalone NC, Faria RP, Pearce JM (2013) Open-Source 3D-Printable Optics Equipment. PLoS ONE 8(3): e59840. This is part of a larger project to reduce the cost of scientific equipment using open-source hardware. Read more here

title: TronXY X5/X5S Cart upgrade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This replacement, as well as the other modifications I mention, will help to alleviate layer shifting and the motors having to do more work than they need to so replace your carts on the TronXY X5S with these. The X5S_Cart-1.stl requires two 6mm aluminum spacers and two 6mm eccentric nuts. X5S_Cart.stl just requires the two 6mm eccentric nuts.

After you do this mod you will notice just how smooth the R and L are and I do mean smooth. If you want to go one even better take the extruder plate off and the bottom wheel hole (of the three holes) drill it out with a 9/32 inch bit (5/16 will also work) and place an eccentric nut there as well. Now due to the lack of thickness of the extruder plate you will need to remove about .1-.2mm from the eccentic so it fits flush but that took me less than a minute on a metal file. My entire system is so so so much better now that I added the five eccentrics in total and you will be amazed as well.

One other side note is that, at least on mine, the 625zz bearings on all wheels were absolutely horrid so I replaced them with 625RS (from AliExpress for less than 12 USD delivered for 50) and this was a HUGE change as well.

The cart replacements can further be used with the various belt alignment mods that are around.

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

Use 100% infill with 5 to 6 shells and ABS/PETG and anything less than 80% is not recommended for these. Use washers with all screws.

comments.text: you also mention to replace the 625zz bearings. What is a good practice to remove them without destroying the outer plastic wheel?
comments.author: robscar

comments.text: These wheels were a PITA to remove those bearings but what I do is find a nice m4 bolt and hold the wheel in my hand and push the bolt at an angle so as to push out one of the bearings.  It takes practice because what you are doing is trying to get the bolt to push on the 1mm space that exists between the two bearings.  This is where a 1mm tiny spacer lives because you will need that spacer as many Tevo Tarantula buyers found out when it first came out (Tevo was so cheap they didn't include the spacer).  Take your time and examine the M5 hole of the wheel and look for the space, and the lip, I am talking about then get something to push on that lip.  As all V-Wheels were made to have their bearings replaced, and not the entire wheel, this is SOP for them.
comments.author: robscar

comments.text: great thanks, I'll squeeze them out :-)
comments.author: DarkAlchemist

comments.text: Thanks for sharing. I have never used eccentric nuts before. How do they stay in place once you turned them to adjust tolerance?  Is it just through the force of the nut and screw?
comments.author: robscar

comments.text: Yes, this is why you tighten the nut and back it off just a little then adjust the eccentric nut and when it is just gripping the extrusion (don't over adjust) you go back and finish tightening the lock nut.
comments.author: robscar

(To use the OpenSCAD file, you will need to include the Metric/M3.scad file. Source is here: https://github.com/b33j0r/Metric)

I like OpenSCAD. I came across this parametric bed bracket for my Hypercube Evolution project and printed it but then I realised I could make it work a bit better for my requirements.

I added a hole in the top to capture the bed spring and I extended the underside so that I could fit a 18mm diameter thumbwheel which would then allow me to easily make small adjustments to the bed height.

Thanks to ThatPlayer for the original design and idea.

I have included the OpenSCAD file. The STL is for a 27.5mm bracket. You will probably not want that. Please use the OpenSCAD file to get the length right for your build.

title: Test pattern for dimensionally accurate openings in 3D printing especially for fusion 360

description.text:
Test pattern for dimensionally accurate openings in 3D printing:

As a rule, all openings are printed smaller than in the construction.
This file is used for correction of integer diameters, metric screws and nuts.

Please note, the holes are already provided with a correction factor, ie slightly larger than the corresponding component.

CSV file with metric nuts and bolts.
This csv file can be easily imported into Fusion 360 as parameter table via plugin "Parameter I / O".
https://apps.autodesk.com/FUSION/en/Detail/Index?id=1801418194626000805&appLang=en&os=Win64
The values ​​can then be used directly in the sketch.

With the stl file you can check the dimensional accuracy of your own printer.
Then adjust the values ​​directly in the csv file or in fusion..

Please also test whether the printer supplies holes in Z and in XY direction other dimensions.

If you use this table in fusion, you can quickly switch to another printer. Of course you must have defined all holes by parameters.

Enclosed also the Fusion 360 file.

I hope it saves you a lot of time and material.

Content of the test print:
M10, M8, M6, M5, M4, M3 each for:

  • Wrench size hex nut
  • Head diameter Inbus screw
  • Screws / shaft diameter in integer mm
    All with a correction factor for larger holes !!

Operating Procedure

  1. Test print. Check if the openings fit.
  2. If necessary, adjust values.

Possibilities of adaptation

  1. In CAD directly.
  2. In the csv file with import to Fusion 360.
  3. Directly in my fusion file.

The table also contains data on the height of the nuts and screw heads.

Mounts to the top 20x20 rail of your printer. Designed around a 3D Solutech spool, wide enough to hold 2 spools. Has a center divider to keep them from locking together. and support the weight. Uses a standard M4 with T nut at the top to hold it locked onto the rail. Rod can go in from either side and sit flush. If mounting for only one spool? Slide the mounts closer together and skip the middle mount.

Designed to stick out the back (or front) parallel to the bed.

Why?

After getting my Tevo Tarantula built, I liked having my dual extruder motors on the top rail. Trouble is, feeding the filament. There are quite a few ways to do this, but for me, I liked this method.

description.text:
This is my own version of, what I've come to realise, is a commonly known puzzle! I first saw it in this video: https://youtu.be/xp-PENvptu0

I was looking for a little experimental project to learn more about 3D printing and in particular about the clearances needed to make matching parts fit well together. In the end I found that adding a buffer of around 0.15mm on each side between parts works well. As it is, these parts straight off the printer do fit, but very tightly. After some working and cleaning they slide just great.

I've also seen other examples of the same puzzle on this site. This is not a remix, it is my own take but admittedly it is very similar.

I also experimented with spray painting the bottom half for contrast. It seems OK for now and I will see how well it holds up to being handled.

Another finish detail experiment that worked well was some inlaid text on the lid that I "flood filled" with some nail polish. I dripped it in using a toothpick and then once dried I just used a knife to scrape off bits that had overflowed onto the lid. I think it gives a very nice labelling effect.

For the magnet I used a 6x3 mm N52 Neodymium Disc: http://r.ebay.com/73SqQq
It is super glued into the recess printed for it in the lid. The press fit was almost tight enough but then the ball would pull it out, so super glue was necessary to make it stay put.

For the ball I used an 11mm ball that my kids had from magnet construction toys.

No supports or rafts needed for this model and I printed with 0.2mm layer height. Took about 10 hours to print both parts side by side.

UPDATE: 05/03/2018 I added files for v2.1 with slightly more clearance so the 2 parts fit together pretty much straight off the printer (thanks to feedback from Qrome).

This is a mold for the ZeroBot tire. I created this as my printer is not really geared for flexible filament and I needed the tire for the great little ZeroBot print.

For the tire I used the oogoo silicone mix which is a mix of 100% silicone, Corn starch and food colouring(if you want to colour it). Google should give you a few results for oogoo if you want to see how its made.

To use the mold assemble the inner and outer parts, tighten with an 8mm bolt, washers and nut. Fill the tire space with the oogoo until you get some coming out the small holes. Then loosen the bolt, add some more oogoo to the mold put on the top then tighten the bolt again and let it dry.

title: RC Crawler Tank
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my second RC Tank, on this version i wanted to focus on speed and all terrain capability.

This version was designed so that all the parts could be 3D printed. You will need to purchase some fasteners and bearings:

M3 x 40mm button head screws for the tracks
M3 x 12mm button head screws for the frame
M3 nylon locking nuts for tracks and frame
12 x 6000 size bearings
2 x 540 size motors (I use 55T)
ESC drives for the motors
1 or 2 batteries used for quadcopters and planes
M3 Push Fit Thread inserts (4mm OD, 5mm L)

the Axels and mounting pillars all need the threaded insert to work properly.

The tracks do fit nicely around the frame but i have not put them into the assembly as it was not needed (and difficult)

as for the electronics i have designed my own controller and motherboard.

Feel free to ask me about my board and if you want the designs and firmware, if not you can use your own controller and receiver. My board uses a HC-12 module capable of 1km rage. My device also has stall detection on each side and temperature monitoring on each of the motors and ESC. The PCB Panel Part has mounting pillars for the motherboard PCB

There are mounting holes for the communication antennas (Both FPV and Controller Antennas), there is also a toggle switch mounting hole.

Any Questions or find any missing parts just leave me a message / comment and i will try to reply!

title: BLTouch mount for itworks3d.com Taz 6 toolhead

description.text:
This is a small and simple mount for the BLTouch for the itworks3d.com Titan Aero extruder for the Taz.

Mount the BLTouch using M3 inserts and appropriate screws/washers - the z offset will be around -1.0mm - do this before you mount the whole thing. You can adjust the offset downward with the addition of washers between the BLTouch and the mount - the mount is designed and verified to put the BLTouch probe tip at the recommended 3mm+/- above the tip of the nozzle when the probe is stowed.

The mount then attaches to the right side of the tool head using the holes for the X axis max endstop switch - you will need to pull the M2 inserts from the tool head and reuse them with longer M2 screws. Simply set the M2 inserts into the new mount and run the new longer M2 screws (14mm will do) though the switch, the holes in the tool head where the M2 inserts were and into the newly placed M2 inserts in the BLTouch mount.

title: The Othercam: a simple Chromebook/Laptop camera flip

description.text:
The frustrating thing about a Chromebook or laptop is trying to take a picture or photo with it. I made this little device to make it a little easier for kids to film each other or take pictures of their work. I always keep one on my desk that they borrow. Kids simply place the "Othercam" on top of their laptop with the mirror facing the camera, tilt their screen to get their subject in frame, then record a video or take a picture.

This build requires a small (3 x 7.5 cm) mirror. I used an inexpensive plastic mirror from the Dollar store and cut it up to make a few of there to pass out to teachers in our school.

title: Rad Radius Gauge - the RadGauge - With Companion App
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A rad radius gauge for measuring radii of around 40 mm and bigger. Use the free web app calculator to calculate the result, it's super easy!

The companion app and instructions for use:

https://subsite.github.io/rad/

Now this is made to fit my digital calipers, which is pretty standard. The main shaft is around 16 mm x 4 mm, and it has a screw to keep the depth probe in place. To test if it fits, you can first print the small test piece, and then the complete model if it fits. A bit loose is ok, it's easy to keep in place while measuring.

If it's too tight vertically (z-axis), you could try to scale the z-axis in your slicer. Don't scale the whole thing, or the measuring distance will be off.

It's probably pretty easy for me to make another version for a different set of calipers, please let me know, and I'll see what I can do!

Please post a Make if you make this!

title: Skipping Rope Handles with Threaded Caps
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Skipping rope handles with detachable screw-down caps.

UPDATE 02/03/18 - Modifed STL files for intended printing orientation.

I created these for my 5 yr old daughter after she asked me to buy her a set from a shop... I thought I could do better (and for cheaper) so here we go.

Should be fairly straightforward to print. PLA is fine for these. Print two each of 'Cap Body' and 'Handle Body' STL files. I printed them in different colours, as per photographs, for a nicer look.

I used 8mm climbing rope (not sure of composition, possible cotton/polyester, possibly nylon) but it should be good quality rope with a decent weight to it. Determine correct length of rope for height of individual (http://www.rxsmartgear.com/how-to-size-your-rope/)
thread the caps on and tie a single simple knot to secure, trim and screw cap down to handle body. Repeat for other end, and enjoy!

description.text:
Just some small round silica gel containers. I created these to throw in the middle of my filament spools before I vacuum seal them or throw them in a zip lock back with the filament roll.

I fill the containers with Dry & Dry Blue Indicating Silica Gel. I buy it from Amazon, https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B019NN1GBG/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1.

There are two types, slip fitting lids and threaded lids. If you're printer can do the threads, I'd make the threaded version. I made the mistake of dropping one of these and it split open, I adjusted them to make that a little harder but that's not going to happen at all with the threads (I tested.) I've also added a few lid files so you can print more than one lid at a time for those of you using a slicer that only supports one model.

Resolution:

Notes:

I printed these using PETG so I could microwave them on defrost to reactivate the silica gel without the container melting.

I also had problems every time I tried to print both the container and lid at the same time. My nozzle would eventually knock over parts on the container when it switches between the different objects. That's actually why there are so many horizontal supports. I included the combined .stl files anyway in case your printer works better than mine for it. Maybe if I reverse the origines it'll help with that, I'll give it a try and update the .stl's if it works.

2 VERSIONS- the one labeled with LARGE will fit a standard 1kg spool which is about 68 mm thick/wide. The smaller one is measured for some smaller spools including the ones that are broken free from the XYZ filament cartridges. I still like to use these if I need to respool some filament so that I am able to print the same stuff on two printers at once.

I made this because there just weren't any good ones yet which did not use any hardware. These have not yet been fully tested except for the teeth which slide into the extrusion. If anyone tries it out leave comment and let me know if needs any change. Thanks.

Joining Batterys and Module

Join all 5 batterys together in paralell, either by soldering or welding.
Then insert the module into the front part and keep it in place with hot glue.
Next step is to solder the battery wires onto the module with shortest cable thats possible for you(always check the polarity).

I had to use my vice due to bad printer tollerance.
Thats it ! - Charge and use it for whatever you need :)

Good luck with this one, it's a beast!
Colin

description.text:
These are printable extensions to turn a standard 19 mm piece size 3x3x3 Rubik's cube into a Pocket Cube, an extended version of a "lines and quads" bandaged cube.

There are two versions included. The offset files include extensions that will entirely cover the cube, making all the surfaces the same material and color for either painting or in theory, a stickerless version. This comes at the cost of the small 2x2x2 section being slightly disproportionate. This should be somewhat visible in my example in the included images.

The Flush version does not use the thin caps, extending only where needed, and keeping the cube proportional. You will of course have to fill in crevices on exposed bandaged pieces. This is the version you'd likely use if you wanted to paint it black and sticker it afterwards.

Offset print:
OffsetCenterCap x 3
OffsetCornerCap x 3
OffsetEdgeCap x 6
OffsetCornerExt x 1
OffsetLineExt x 3
OffsetQuadExt x 3

Flush print:
FlushCornerExt x 1
FlushLineExt x 3
FlushQuadExt x 3

Due to slight variances in printer tolerances and cube sizes, I would recommend printing out one of the larger extension pieces and fitting it to your cube. If it seems to rub against other pieces as it turns, shrink all the models down a very small percentage (~1% or less).

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

You need supports only for the corner extensions. The rest can be printed flat one way or another.

Assembly

I recommend gluing the bandaged pieces together before gluing on extensions for added durability and alignment.

The images included and those at the link here should give you a good idea of which pieces to glue together.

http://twistypuzzles.com/cgi-bin/puzzle.cgi?pkey=4481

author: Ghostsniper89

description.text: Minor Modifications

This is an improved filament runout sensor mount for the CR-10.
I have constrained the filament path to the minimal it needs right up to cutaway for the lever of the switch to move. I have created a path that should lead right into your extruder at the right height and position. I have specifically designed it to work with the EXR Struder by SeeMeCNC, but it seems to align well with stock and aluminum versions.

Be sure when screwing it to the 2 screws which mount your bearing on the Z rods, that you dont tighten the screws too much this may constrain the bearing from moving into the most comfortable position for it to allow for free movement.

Also look at my tape fix for the metal switch lever, this is probably the main reason every one has problems inserting filament.

I did make it to mount a PFTE tube at the entrance, I find this helps filament to bend and align with new path to extruder from the reel without allowing the filament to wear down the sensor mount.

print with no supports. both parts laying on their flat backs and open clam shell upward.
I print at 0.1 layer height and slow 35mm/s to get all of the detail sharp.

You will need 2 socket head or button head M3 x 10mm and 3 countersunk M3 x 10mm

I like to keep assortments such as:
http://a.co/8sZ7tY4

or full assortment:
http://a.co/1QCcfcb

and 3 countersunk M3 x 10:
http://a.co/h1ciAqL

1 30mm length of PFTE tubing, cut with sharp razor (not scissors), flair exposed end a bit with a Phillips screw driver

If you make one please post your 'make' photos.

••••Update March 2 files filambox5 have been updated with a slightly adjusted height to better align path to extruder, have repaired some internal issues. Have opened the rear screw mount so you can leave the brass bearing connected with one screw, just raised, slip it on, then screw in second.

Updates on Base6 made opening at higher angle to ease mounting without removing rear screw, still to be tested.

*** Update March 4, following a few user tests and comments I have made version 7.
the screw holes have been made longer and countersinks wider to accommodate standard screws from stock filament holder. I have also made oval openings for screw mounts to allow more flexibility in mounting and less stress on bearing position. For this reason I was also forced to remove the open ended top screw.

thanks!

I wanted a simple way to mount a fan on my solidoodle3, but finding an elegant design was tough because i had an e3d hotend installed. In desperation i put a magnet on a screw in the corner of an 80mm fan that i had directly wired to a 12v power supply and stuck it to the x axis rods where it sticks out the end of the carriage - and it worked!  
With this in mind i created a very simple holder than  uses 4 8mm magnets and two screws and 2 nuts. There is not gluing required; everything can be disassembled if you don't like it!   
This design also cools one of the motors.

1) Print the part - no support . I did 5% infill.  
2) Sandwich the object between the 2 pairs of magnets in the holes provided. you will notice that the magnets stick out further on one side - this is on purpose.  
3) screw the holder to the fan. Make sure the side where the magnets stick out farther is facing away from the fan  
Check out the attached pictures to see how it goes together.

This is a python script to map a grayscale image as a height map onto the inside or outside of a hollow sphere. The result is a spherical lithophane.

It is an updated version of my previous Thing.

The first photo shows the progress of geodesic_g27_inside_200_drilled.stl after 6h of printing on my Wanhao i3.

Printer:

Wanhao i3 v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

New approach

In my previous Thing, I based the sphere on spherical coordinates using a rectangular mesh of latitude and longitude angles. The disadvantage of that approach is the unnecessarily dense mesh it generates at the poles of the globe.

Not only does this result in a lot of vertices and faces which need to be handled by the slicer, even the script generating the mesh could easily run for hours in order to get a decent equatorial resolution.

In order to circumvent this problem I remembered an object class in the virtual 3D world ov the raytracer POV-Ray which I played around with almost 20 years ago: the geodesic sphere.

Meet the Geodesic Sphere

A spherical object can be created if you start with a regular icosahedron. As one of the five Platonic solids it consists of 20 equilateral triangles.

By subsequent subdivision of each of the faces into smaller triangles you will get smoother and smoother approximations to a sphere. Geodesics are widely used in architecture to construct round dome shapes - often from glass panes and metal struts.

Original idea

A couple of weeks ago I saw the YouTube video where RCLifeOn presented his spherical lithophane globe. He used Autodesk 3ds Max to design the object, where he placed the height map on the outside of the globe, but I immediately wondered how it would look like when the height map was hidden inside the globe.

RCLifeOn has also posted his globe here on Thingiverse.

Free and open source?

Not having access to this piece of software I researched if I could get a similar result using free tools. My favorite OpenSCAD does not (yet?) support mapping of bitmap files onto non-flat surfaces, so I had to look further.

I quickly found an example on how to create an .stl file in python and started to experiment. My first output was a simple cube, before I put all pieces together:

  • scaling an image
  • creating a sphere
  • creating a second sphere
  • putting the two spheres into each other
  • modifying the thickness of the wall by means of the map
Implementation

The map I use is the free height map image of the world by NASA. I now added the map itself and a modified version with a gamma setting of 2.7 which might give a better contrast between the oceans and continents.

In the Python script itself you can modify a couple of things

  • the outer diameter of the sphere
  • the number of subdivisions of the geodesic object, starting at 10 pixels around the equator for a frequency of 1, this number can be increased e.g. to about 2000 pixels around the equator for a frequency of 200
  • the thickness of the wall for the black portions of the mapped image
  • the depth of the carving from the outside in
  • the depth of the carving from the inside out
  • the filename of the image to be carved out of the wall of the sphere
The files

the included files are:

// the main script
geodesic_mapped_double.py              

// a 120 mm sphere with the world on the inside at freq=200
// wall thickness 3 mm, carving depth 2.2 mm
geodesic_g27_inside_200.stl            

// - the same sphere with a 15 mm diameter hole at the south pole 
geodesic_g27_inside_200_drilled.stl    

// a 120 mm sphere with the world on the outside at freq=200
// wall thickness 3 mm, carving depth 2.2 mm
geodesic_g27_outside_200.stl            

// - the same sphere with a 15 mm diameter hole at the south pole 
geodesic_g27_outside_200_drilled.stl    

// checkerboard patterned sphere - carved from the outside, freq=100
geodesic_test_outside_100.stl          
// checkerboard patterned sphere - carved from the outside, freq=100
geodesic_test_inside_100.stl
// checkerboard patterned sphere - carved from the outside, freq=100
geodesic_test_inoutside_100.stl

// the same three spheres cut open
geodesic_test_outside_100_cut.stl
geodesic_test_inside_100_cut.stl      
geodesic_test_inoutside_100_cut.stl    

geodesic_demo_1.stl    // just a geodesic object, freq=1
geodesic_demo_2.stl    //                         freq=2
geodesic_demo_4.stl    //                         freq=3
geodesic_demo_3.stl    //                         freq=4
geodesic_demo_5.stl    //                         freq=5
geodesic_demo_6.stl    //                         freq=6

description.text:
I found the reel holder supplied with the printer is a bit draggy and not best, especially for TPU. I obtained some 4mm tungsten carbide amalgum rod. Steel would do or stainless. Use this as an axle and print these items and the reel rolls with little resistance, so no starvation on TPU builds, etc.

Example product. Not exactly the one I bought, but similar things can be found.
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/3-12mm-K20-Tungsten-Carbide-100mm-Rod-Boring-Bar-Lathe-CNC-Tool-Maker-Endmill-UK-/311156663660?var=&hash=item487261e56c

These reel-holders cater for e-sun 500g, e-sun 1kg and TPU reels. I've not seen other reel profiles yet, but other centres could be made. The chevron design makes for extra toughness in a light design.

Yes, I know the holder does not quite cater for the TPU reel, but a few of bits of blu-tack or sticky-fixers soon solves that one, on the ends of the rod and on the feet of the holder.

description.text:
A replica of the 8 x 56 mm Rimmed rifle cartridge developed in 1930 for the Steyr 1895 straight-pull bolt-action rifle, the service rifle of Austra-Hungary in World War I; many such rifles were converted from their original round-nosed 8 x 50 to the pointed-nosed (Spitzer) 8 x 56 during the 1930s, and historical/surplus M1895 rifles can often be found in the newer chambering. The CIP calls this cartridge "8×56mmR M30S".

Dimensions were taken from new production Prvi Partisan ammunition, and the model built in FreeCAD. The completed ABS "snap cap" (inert replica used to test-fire a gun without leaving the chamber empty) was tested in a Steyr-made M1895/30 carbine.

As this is a digital copy of a design that's 88 years old, it's entirely in the public domain.

author: joerenkin

description.text:
---- Sanding required for snug fit. ---- Fine Sandpaper will do. (P400)
The cylinder slides free if the all the pins are aligned correctly, so I would recommend to add some kind of restrainer to prevent the cylinder from sliding out.

I would recommend placing the bed a bit closer (paper thickness + slight friction) to the nozzle so both sides of the lock look nice.

The lock works best/smoothest when both the cylinder and the cylinder holder are exactly aligned. You can do this by pushing them flat on a flat surface.

TODO:

  • Add a mover thingy and retainers to ensure that the cylinder stays in place.
  • Add some kind of arm that the key moves when its unlocked.

Instructions:

  1. Print The Key (Key.stl)
  2. Print The Lock Cylinder (Cylinder.stl)
  3. Print The Outside Housing (CylinderHolder.stl)
  4. Print Three of the Locking Pins (3XLockPin.stl)
  5. Print Each one of the pins (PinA.stl, PinB.stl, PinC.stl)
  6. Sandpaper the outside of the Lock Cylinder and the inside of the cylinder Housing.
  7. When both of these pieces fit snug together proceed to assembly.

Assembly:

  1. Align all the pins to the key. (Biggest Pin to smallest groove and vice versa)
  2. Place all the pins in the correct order into the cylinder.
  3. Ensure that they all lay flat when the key is inserted (View image).
  4. Remove the key slowly and insert the cylinder with the pins into the cylinder holder.
  5. Insert the last 3 big locking pins into the cylinder holder.
  6. Assure everything is lined up and flush with each other.
  7. The lock should now work correctly.

Known Issues:
Trouble inserting or removing the key: Ensure that both cylinders are flat together.
Pins are getting stuck: Sand the pin slots/holes.

This is a functional Work In Progress project.

Please share and like if you enjoyed this project.

Anet A8

Extruder Temp 200C.
Tolerance is about 0.25mm diameter on the cylinder wheel to holder. (0.5mm total)
Key and pin tolerances are 0.5mm both sides (1mm total)
Pin tolerances are the same for the key.

description.header:
Here's my design for a tool holder that is attached to my Printrbot Simple on the Simple Tower.
This keeps all those little keys contained in one accessible spot instead of hiding in the tool drawer!
The openings are designed to hold a Craftsman 5/16" box wrench, 2.5mm allen key, 1/16" allen key, and 1.5mm allen key, in order. I was able to pick up all 4 tools for less than $10 from all-US sellers on eBay. There are also two small pilot holes in place to be drilled to any mounting size you require.
Enjoy and happy extruding!

description.text:
• Print out the design (no supports needed)
  • Run the allen keys through their respective holes to clean out any stray hairs
  • Drill and countersink the mounting holes if required
  • Mount it on the side of your 'bot
  • Never lose one of those keys again!

description.text:
I had to replace the MOSFET in my CR-10S. The replacement was too large to fit in the original case and that was the perfect justification to redesign the case and mount the components underneath the printer plus clean up all those wires.

It mounts under the front aluminum extrusion and angles down at 45 degrees. It will need feet extensions to provide adequate clearances.

I noticed clearance for the circuit board was a little tight and pinching was causing LCD issues. Version 2 creates the necessary clearances and also gives the screws a little wiggle room.

There will be more parts like a main board case that also accommodates the large MKS MOSFET and a RasperryPi 3, power supply hangers, and a RaspberryPi camera mount.

print_settings.Notes:: This is a pretty straightforward print.

description.text:
My wife and I love the Arkham Horror LCG put out by Fantasy Flight Games. I've lost track of our decks a couple of times, forcing us to restart a campaign. I decided to make an insert for the core box that will allow me to track everything. As you can see, the insert has space for six decks and a ton of tokens. One of the boxes is large enough to hold a handful of miniatures. We're using some from the Mansions of Madness 2nd Edition board game from the same company. The way I'm currently using it is to hold the 4 player decks and the upcoming scenario. The black bag has the current scenario's doom tokens. I keep everything else in a proper card storage box and binder. You can also see the Lola Hayes Role Selector on top of the doom token bag.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2750956

The insert is modular and designed to be taken out of the box and used when playing. The deck holders can be used to keep your deck from sliding around while playing. I should note that this works great with both FFG and Dragon Shield sleeves. The item marked as "discard" can be used either as a little vertical discard pile or for the Agenda and Act decks in AH.

Due to the boxes being the exact same size, this will also work with the Android Netrunner Revised Core and the Legend of the Five Rings (L5R) Core. I checked and it'll hold all the tokens for both.

You'll need to print...
6x Card Holders
2x Small Boxes
2x Medium Boxes
2x Discards
1x Miniatures Holder

I printed everything at a 0.20mm layer height. It took awhile to print all the parts, but it's totally worth it.

I will also be making deck boxes for the rest of KDM using this framework.

Tips appreciated but not required i made this to share so if you are printing for other please don't price gouge

description.text: My mon just asked me some stuff to put in her new garden, so this simple piece will bring some new breath =] !

Printer:

Sethi AIP A3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 - 03 mm

Infill:

0%

Notes:

Use Spiralize contour and be Happy;

Made to fit clipper lighters perfectly.
Make sure and print in spiral vase mode and have 1.2mm of bottom layers to give a sturdy base and also so the plug comes away easily... you'll see what i mean.
print in any colour you like (transparent neon is a personal favorite) and as its in spiral vase mode only weigh 2.1 grams!!

alternately you could scale up 1 or 2 percent and have more perimeters just hollow infill and 0 top layers ... yet to try.

look forward to seeing makes!

enjoy!
